source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: AES study of a heated zirconium specimen exposed to small pressures of iodine [11]. The intensity of the AES signal due to iodine chemisorbed on the zirconium surface was measured as a function of the flux of iodine gas (equivalent to iodine atom pressures in the range of 10^-9 to 10^-11 atm) impinging on the surface at temperatures from 1000 to 1300 K

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: The enthalpy of formation of the chemisorbed iodine was found to be $- 1 4 6 \mathrm { \bf ~ k J }$ per gram atom of iodine chemisorbed

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: independent of coverage in the range of approximately one monolayer

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: Below $\pmb { 8 5 0 K }$ solid zirconium monoiodide is formed so that the pressures are determined by the Zr$Z r I _ { 1 . 1 }$ solid equilibrium

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: Above $8 5 0 ~ K$ all the iodine is in vapor species and the pressures are controlled by equilibrium with the metal

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: Above about $1 6 5 0 K$ the dominant species becomes monatomic iodine

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: Below $1 2 5 0 ~ K$ the chemisorbed monolayer is formed so that the pressures are determined by the zirconium-chemisorbed monolayer equilibrium

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: Above $1 2 5 0 K$ all the iodine is in vapor species and pressures are controlled by equilibrium with metal

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: monatomic iodine is the dominant vapor species over the entire range of temperature

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: At $6 0 0 ~ \mathbf { K }$ most of the iodine is in the chemisorbed monolayer, and its pressure in the vapor is about $1 0 ^ { - 1 9 }$ atm

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: at $6 0 0 \mathrm { \bf K }$ the partial pressure of iodine over the two-solid-phase system $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } / \mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } \mathbf { I } _ { 1 , 1 }$ is about $1 0 ^ { - 1 5 }$ atm

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: in the system with a chemisorbed monolayer it is about $1 0 ^ { - 1 9 }$ atm

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: the thermodynamic driving force or free-energy change for transfer of iodine from $\mathbf { Z r l } _ { 1 , 1 }$ to the chemisorbed monolayer is RT1n $( 1 \bar { 0 } ^ { - 1 5 } / 1 0 ^ { - 1 9 } )$ or about $- 4 6 \ k J / \mathbf { g }$ atom of iodine

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: The Gibbs free-energy change for the reaction $0 . 3 7 \mathrm { \ A l I } _ { 3 } ( s ) + \mathrm { Z r } ( s ) = \mathrm { Z r I } _ { 1 . 1 } ( s ) + 0 . 3 7 \mathrm { \ A l } ( s )$ is about $- 4 0  { k J }$ at $6 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { K } }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: The Gibbs free-energy change for its reaction with zirconium to form ${ \bf { Z r l } } _ { 1 . 1 }$ is about $- 7 5 \ \mathbf { k J }$ at $6 0 0 ~ \mathrm { \bf K }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: Peehs et al [13,14] have studied the influence of iodine concentration on SCC of Zircaloy

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: when they released small amounts of iodine $( < 1 0 ^ { - 3 } \ \mathbf { g } / \mathbf { c m } ^ { 2 } )$ near a stressed Zircaloy surface, microcracks initiated in "islands"

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: release of small amounts of iodine near a stressed flaw would cause SCC, but, if released far from the flaw, would not

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: The minimum surface concentration that caused SCC in the test of Peehs et al [13, 14] $( \sim 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 6 } \mathbf { g }$ iodine per square centimetre of Zircaloy)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: the Peehs et al. value would represent about $1 5 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 5 }$ atoms of iodine per square centimetre or about 30 monolayers of iodine over the entire surface

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: the partial pressure of monatomic iodine in equilibrium with a monolayer of chemisorbed iodine is about $1 0 ^ { - 1 9 }$ atm at $\bf { 6 0 0 1 }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: Smaller pressures are required for fractional monolayer coverage ( $1 0 ^ { - 2 2 }$ atm for 0.1 monolayer)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: The standard Gibbs free-energy change for that reaction calculated from literature data $[ 6 , l 8 - 2 0 ]$ is given by the relation $\Delta G ^ { 0 } \left( T \right) , \mathrm { k J } = 2 5 \pm 1 4 - ( 0 . 0 2 4 \pm 0 . 0 1 1 ) T$

evidence_span: The oxygen potential in a fuel rod [21,22] is about $- 4 1 0 \pm 3 0 \mathrm { \ k J / m o l \ O _ { 2 } }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: crack initiation sites in iodine SCC in commercial Zircaloy tubing are associated with local higher-than-normal concentrations of impurities (iron, chromium, aluminum, silicon and others)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: In a study of two lots (A and B) of commercial Zircaloy-2 tubing made to the same manufacturing specifications [29], we found that one lot (B) failed in much shorter times than the other lot (A)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: about $6 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { { m } }$ from the inside wall thickness was removed with abrasive papers and diamond-impregnated polishing cloths. The time-to-failure of the tubing increased 20-fold

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: The band of material (about 0.01 mm wide and about 0.2 mm long), extending upward from the hole contained a few percent of iron and iodine and some chromium and silicon
composition_raw: Fe: few%, I: few%, Cr: some, Si: some

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk3
evidence_span: Another lot of Zircaloy-2 tubing tested in our laboratory was found to be more resistant to iodine-induced SCC than any batch of commercial tubing we had encountered

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: crack initiation occurs at sites in the Zircaloy surfaces that have local concentrations of impurity elements

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Ferrill and Minassian found iron-rich inclusions associated with premature failure of Zircaloy in tension tests without iodine

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: brittle, iron-containing grain boundary inclusions crack at small strains

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Crack initiation is probably the most time-consuming part of the overall failure process in iodine-induced SCC of Zircaloys

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: The reaction of iodine with unprotected zirconium or Zircaloy occurs fairly rapidly to produce surface layers of solid zirconium iodides

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Capsule experiments in which Zircaloy was exposed to ZrI4 vapor and examined by scanning electron microscopy showed that the surface sites that reacted most were regions containing impurities such as iron, silicon, and titanium
composition_raw: impurities such as iron, silicon, and titanium

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: we have found iodine incorporated into the material containing impurities even after ion milling to remove surface layers

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: the resulting local site of reacted material (zirconium plus impurity plus iodine) has properties different from the surrounding matrix such that when the material is strained, cracks form between the reaction sites and the surrounding matrix

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: the surface impurity centers extend only a small distance through the tubing wall

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: crack initiation in commercial Zircaloy tubing occurs at local sites containing impurities

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: The size and nature of the sites determine the susceptibility of the material to iodine-induced SCC

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: these sites are formed during tube-forming operations

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: The significant difference between the two rods was the degree of fission-gas release (0.2 versus 14.3 percent).

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: The significant difference between the two rods was the degree of fission-gas release (0.2 versus 14.3 percent).

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: The high-gas-release rod contained a significantly greater amount of fissionproduct deposits

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: in some areas, breaks in the inner-surface oxide were observed

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: The cladding specimens, with the fuel removed, were subjected to stress-rupture tests in an iodine environment using internal gas pressurization to evaluate their stress corrosion cracking (SCC) susceptibility.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: The results suggest that the inner-surface oxide provides a barrier to iodine penetration.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: Hence, the thick unbreached oxide on the low-gas-release rod provided greater resistance to iodine SCC than the breached oxide on the high-gas-release rod.
